code: @Manual{,   title = {triptych: Diagnostic Graphics to Evaluate Forecast Performance},   author = {Timo Dimitriadis and Alexander I. Jordan},   year = {2023},   note = {https://github.com/aijordan/triptych/, https://aijordan.github.io/triptych/}, }

what: Diagnostic Graphics to Evaluate Forecast Performance
title: Diagnostic Graphics to Evaluate Forecast Performance
text: Overall predictive performance measured mean score (loss), decomposes miscalibration, discrimination, uncertainty components. main focus visualization distinct complementary aspects joint displays. See Dimitriadis, Gneiting, Jordan, Vogel (2023) arXiv:2301.10803.

title: Diagnostic Graphics to Evaluate Forecast Performance
text: (Soon) Install latest release triptych CRAN : Install development version triptych :
code: install.packages("triptych") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("aijordan/triptych")

title: Diagnostic Graphics to Evaluate Forecast Performance
code: library(triptych) data(ex_binary, package = "triptych") set.seed(20230921)  # Construct and inspect tr <- triptych(ex_binary) # or: tr <- triptych(ex_binary[2:11], ex_binary[1]) tr #> # A tibble: 10 × 5 #>    forecast          murphy     reliability             roc          mcbdsc #>    <chr>         <trpt_mur>      <trpt_rel>      <trpt_roc>   <trpt_mcbdsc> #>  1 X01      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  2 X02      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  3 X03      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  4 X04      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  5 X05      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  6 X06      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  7 X07      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  8 X08      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  9 X09      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #> 10 X10      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> class(tr) #> [1] "triptych"   "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"  # 1. Choose 4 predictions # 2. Add consistency bands (for reliability curves) # 3. Create patchwork object # 4. Adjust the title of the legend dplyr::slice(tr, 1, 3, 6, 9) |>   add_consistency(level = 0.9, n_boot = 100) |>   autoplot() &   ggplot2::guides(colour = ggplot2::guide_legend("Forecast")) # From existing triptych object estimates(tr$mcbdsc) #> # A tibble: 10 × 5 #>    forecast mean_score     MCB    DSC   UNC #>    <chr>         <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 X01          0.0827 0.00474 0.172  0.250 #>  2 X02          0.127  0.0233  0.146  0.250 #>  3 X03          0.134  0.0172  0.132  0.250 #>  4 X04          0.194  0.0587  0.114  0.250 #>  5 X05          0.222  0.0723  0.100  0.250 #>  6 X06          0.180  0.00494 0.0748 0.250 #>  7 X07          0.212  0.0211  0.0590 0.250 #>  8 X08          0.235  0.0263  0.0410 0.250 #>  9 X09          0.303  0.0818  0.0282 0.250 #> 10 X10          0.312  0.0772  0.0148 0.250 autoplot(tr$mcbdsc) # Or standalone: # mcbdsc(ex_binary) |> estimates() # mcbdsc(ex_binary) |> autoplot()

title: Accessing original forecast and observation data for triptych objects — accessors
Adding confidence regions — add_confidence
text: Confidence regions supposed contain true "parameter" given degree confidence. , "parameter" refers murphy curve, reliability curve, ROC curve, respectively.

title: Adding confidence regions — add_confidence
code: add_confidence(x, level = 0.9, method = "resampling_cases", ...)

title: Adding confidence regions — add_confidence
text: x object confidence region added. level single value level confidence. method string gives name method generate confidence regions. Currently, one : "resampling_cases", "resampling_Bernoulli". ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Adding confidence regions — add_confidence
text: object given x, information confidence regions. information can accessed conveniently using regions() curve component interest.

title: Adding confidence regions — add_confidence
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych")  # Construct triptych object and select 2 forecasts tr <- triptych(ex_binary) |>   dplyr::slice(1, 9)  # Bootstrap resampling is expensive # (the number of bootstrap samples is small to keep execution times short) tr <- add_confidence(tr, level = 0.9, method = "resampling_cases", n_boot = 20) regions(tr$murphy) #> # A tibble: 2,000 × 6 #>    forecast threshold    lower    upper method              level #>    <chr>        <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl> <chr>               <dbl> #>  1 X01        0       0        0        resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  2 X01        0.00100 0.000665 0.000753 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  3 X01        0.00200 0.00127  0.00142  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  4 X01        0.00300 0.00183  0.00205  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  5 X01        0.00400 0.00234  0.00267  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  6 X01        0.00501 0.00286  0.00330  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  7 X01        0.00601 0.00333  0.00388  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  8 X01        0.00701 0.00378  0.00441  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  9 X01        0.00801 0.00426  0.00496  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> 10 X01        0.00901 0.00479  0.00555  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> # ℹ 1,990 more rows regions(tr$reliability) #> # A tibble: 1,998 × 6 #>    forecast        x lower upper method              level #>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>               <dbl> #>  1 X01      1.19e-23     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  2 X01      3.84e-23     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  3 X01      9.45e-22     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  4 X01      9.82e-20     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  5 X01      1.13e-19     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  6 X01      4.73e-17     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  7 X01      1.40e-16     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  8 X01      6.33e-16     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  9 X01      1.48e-15     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> 10 X01      7.97e-15     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> # ℹ 1,988 more rows regions(tr$roc) #> # A tibble: 4,004 × 5 #>    forecast   FAR      HR method              level #>    <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>               <dbl> #>  1 X01          0 0       resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  2 X01          0 0.00209 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  3 X01          0 0.00418 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  4 X01          0 0.00628 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  5 X01          0 0.00837 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  6 X01          0 0.0105  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  7 X01          0 0.0126  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  8 X01          0 0.0146  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  9 X01          0 0.0167  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> 10 X01          0 0.0188  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> # ℹ 3,994 more rows

what: Adding consistency regions for reliability curves — add_consistency
title: Adding consistency regions for reliability curves — add_consistency
text: Consistency regions created assumption forecasts calibrated. reliability curve significantly violates consistency region indicates miscalibrated forecast.

title: Adding consistency regions for reliability curves — add_consistency
code: add_consistency(x, level = 0.9, method = "resampling_Bernoulli", ...)

title: Adding consistency regions for reliability curves — add_consistency
text: x object consistency region added. level single value level confidence. method string gives name method generate consistency regions. Currently, one : "resampling_cases", "resampling_Bernoulli". ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Adding consistency regions for reliability curves — add_consistency
text: object given x, information consistency regions. information can accessed conveniently using regions() reliability curve component.

title: Adding consistency regions for reliability curves — add_consistency
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych")  # Construct triptych object (with reliability curve component) and select 2 forecasts tr <- triptych(ex_binary) |>   dplyr::slice(1, 9)  # Bootstrap resampling is expensive # (the number of bootstrap samples is small to keep execution times short) tr <- add_consistency(tr, level = 0.9, method = "resampling_Bernoulli", n_boot = 20) regions(tr$reliability) #> # A tibble: 1,998 × 6 #>    forecast        x lower upper method                  level #>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>                   <dbl> #>  1 X01      1.19e-23     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #>  2 X01      3.84e-23     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #>  3 X01      9.45e-22     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #>  4 X01      9.82e-20     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #>  5 X01      1.13e-19     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #>  6 X01      4.73e-17     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #>  7 X01      1.40e-16     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #>  8 X01      6.33e-16     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #>  9 X01      1.48e-15     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #> 10 X01      7.97e-15     0     0 resampling_Bernoulli_20   0.9 #> # ℹ 1,988 more rows

title: Accessing diagnostic estimate data — estimates
text: Accessing diagnostic estimate data

title: Accessing diagnostic estimate data — estimates
code: estimates(x, at, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_mcbdsc estimates(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_murphy estimates(x, at = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_reliability estimates(x, at = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_roc estimates(x, at = NULL, p1 = mean(observations(x)), ...)

title: Accessing diagnostic estimate data — estimates
text: x object estimate information extracted. vector thresholds x evaluated. ... Additional arguments passed methods. p1 unconditional event probability. Used combination determine diagonal lines along determine estimate.

title: Accessing diagnostic estimate data — estimates
text: tibble relevant information describing diagnostic estimate (Murphy curve, reliability curve, ROC curve, score decomposition) supplied forecasting methods. Murphy curve, tibble columns: forecast, knot (threshold value), limit ("left" "right" knot, present = NULL), mean_score. reliability curve, tibble columns: forecast, CEP, x (knots isotonic regression estimate). ROC curve, tibble columns: forecast, FAR (false alarm rate), HR (hit rate). MCBDSC decomposition, tibble columns: forecast, mean_score, MCB (miscalibration), DSC (discrimination), UNC (uncertainty).

title: Accessing diagnostic estimate data — estimates

what: Example data set of binary observations and probability forecasts — ex_binary
title: Example data set of binary observations and probability forecasts — ex_binary
text: forecasts X01 X10 generated way discrimination ability neatly decreasing. addition, X01 X06 "calibrated", X02 X07 "underconfident", X03 X08 "overconfident", X04 X09 exhibit "negative bias", X05 X10 exhibit "positive bias".

title: Example data set of binary observations and probability forecasts — ex_binary
code: ex_binary

title: Example data set of binary observations and probability forecasts — ex_binary
text: data frame 1,000 rows 11 columns, generated described 'Details': y observations X01 forecasts, full information, calibrated: \(= 1\), \(b = 1\) X02 forecasts, less information X01, underconfident: \(= 1/4\), \(b = 1/4\) X03 forecasts, less information X02, overconfident: \(= 4\), \(b = 4\) X04 forecasts, less information X03, negative bias: \(= 5/3\), \(b = 3/5\) X05 forecasts, less information X04, positive bias: \(= 3/5\), \(b = 5/3\) X06 forecasts, less information X05, calibrated: \(= 1\), \(b = 1\) X07 forecasts, less information X06, underconfident: \(= 1/4\), \(b = 1/4\) X08 forecasts, less information X07, overconfident: \(= 4\), \(b = 4\) X09 forecasts, less information X08, negative bias: \(= 5/3\), \(b = 3/5\) X10 forecasts, least information, positive bias: \(= 2/3\), \(b = 3/2\)

title: Example data set of binary observations and probability forecasts — ex_binary
text: observations generated Bernoulli distribution, success probability determined ten sources information. , probability given $$p = \Phi(\sum_{= 1}^{10} Z_i),$$ \(Z_i\), \(= 1, ..., 10,\) independent standard Gaussian random variables, \(\Phi\) denotes cumulative distribution function standard Gaussian distribution. corresponding forecasts named decreasing order access latent Gaussian variables (, information content). first step, calibrated forecasts generated \(p[j] = \Phi(\frac{1}{j}\sum_{= j}^{10} Z_i)\). Subsequently, probabilities perturbed introduce miscalibration using cumulative distribution function \(F\) beta distribution, yielding final forecasts $$X[j] = F(p[j]; , b),$$ \(\) \(b\) positive shape parameters (see pbeta()).

what: Evaluation of forecasts using score decompositions — mcbdsc
title: Evaluation of forecasts using score decompositions — mcbdsc
text: score decomposition splits mean score three components miscalibration (MCB), discrimination (DSC), uncertainty (UNC). Plotting DSC component MCB component allows quick visual inspection predictive performance many forecasting methods.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using score decompositions — mcbdsc
code: mcbdsc(x, y = NULL, score = "Brier_score", ...)  as_mcbdsc(x, r)

title: Evaluation of forecasts using score decompositions — mcbdsc
text: x data frame, list, matrix, object can coerced tibble. Contains numeric forecasts. y numeric vector observations. missing, column name "y" must present tibble coerced x. score string specifying score function. One : "Brier_score" (default), "log_score", "MR_score". ... Unused. r reference triptych_mcbdsc object whose attributes used casting.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using score decompositions — mcbdsc
text: triptych_mcbdsc object, vctrs_vctr subclass, length equal number forecasting methods supplied x. entry named according corresponding forecasting method, contains list named objects: estimate: data frame score decomposition. region: empty list. Adding confidence regions yet supported. x: numeric vector original forecasts. Access convenient estimates(), regions(), forecasts().

title: Evaluation of forecasts using score decompositions — mcbdsc

what: Evaluation of forecasts using Murphy curves — murphy
title: Evaluation of forecasts using Murphy curves — murphy
text: Murphy curve visualizes economic utility displaying mean elementary scores across threshold values.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using Murphy curves — murphy
code: murphy(x, y = NULL, ref = NULL, ...)  as_murphy(x, r)

title: Evaluation of forecasts using Murphy curves — murphy
text: x data frame, list, matrix, object can coerced tibble. Contains numeric forecasts. y numeric vector observations. missing, column name "y" must present tibble coerced x. ref numeric vector reference forecasts. Can also supplied column name "ref" tibble coerced x. ... Unused. r reference triptych_murphy object whose attributes used casting.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using Murphy curves — murphy
text: triptych_murphy object, vctrs_vctr subclass, length equal number forecasting methods supplied x. entry named according corresponding forecasting method, contains list named objects: estimate: data frame threshold corresponding mean score values. region: Either empty list, data frame point confidence intervals added add_confidence(). x: numeric vector original forecasts. Access convenient estimates(), regions(), forecasts().

title: Evaluation of forecasts using Murphy curves — murphy
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych")  mr <- murphy(ex_binary) mr #> <triptych_murphy[10]> #>             X01             X02             X03             X04             X05  #> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]>  #>             X06             X07             X08             X09             X10  #> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]>   # 1. Choose 4 predictions # 2. Visualize # 3. Adjust the title of the legend mr[c(1, 3, 6, 9)] |>   autoplot() +   ggplot2::guides(colour = ggplot2::guide_legend("Forecast"))     # Build yourself using accessors library(ggplot2) df_est <- estimates(mr[c(1, 3, 6, 9)]) ggplot(df_est) +   geom_path(aes(x = knot, y = mean_score, col = forecast))

what: Plot methods for the triptych classes — plot.triptych
title: Plot methods for the triptych classes — plot.triptych
text: Plot methods triptych classes

title: Plot methods for the triptych classes — plot.triptych
code: # S3 method for triptych plot(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych autoplot(object, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_murphy plot(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_murphy autoplot(object, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_reliability plot(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_reliability autoplot(object, ..., breaks = seq(0, 1, length.out = 11))  # S3 method for triptych_roc plot(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_roc autoplot(object, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_mcbdsc plot(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_mcbdsc autoplot(   object,   ...,   n_isolines = 10,   colour_values = "black",   colour_unc = "#00BF7D",   MCBDSC_repel = FALSE,   MCB_lim = NA,   DSC_lim = NA )

title: Plot methods for the triptych classes — plot.triptych
text: x object inherits one triptych classes. ... Arguments passed autoplot.triptych() methods triptych classes. object object inherits one triptych classes. breaks vector bin boundaries geom_histogram() layer. Set NA disable. n_isolines number isolines showing mean scores. colour_values colour specification passed values argument scale_colour_manual(). Recycled length 1. colour_unc colour specification highlighting UNC component layers. MCBDSC_repel boolean value indicating whether labels placed ggrepel package. MCB_lim plot limits x-axis (MCB component). DSC_lim plot limits y-axis (DSC component).

title: Plot methods for the triptych classes — plot.triptych
text: object class 'triptych': patchwork object (invisibly). triptych objects: ggplot object (invisibly). Every plot() method wraps corresponding autoplot() method, followed explicit print() call. , always draws plot, even assignment within loop.

title: Plot methods for the triptych classes — plot.triptych
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych") tr <- triptych(ex_binary)  dplyr::slice(tr, 1, 3, 6, 9) |> autoplot()  autoplot(tr$murphy)  autoplot(tr$reliability)  autoplot(tr$roc)  autoplot(tr$mcbdsc)

what: Objects exported from other packages — reexports
title: Objects exported from other packages — reexports
text: objects imported packages. Follow links see documentation. ggplot2 autoplot

title: Accessing confidence/consistency region data — regions
text: Accessing confidence/consistency region data

title: Accessing confidence/consistency region data — regions
code: regions(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_mcbdsc regions(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_murphy regions(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_reliability regions(x, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_roc regions(x, ...)

title: Accessing confidence/consistency region data — regions
text: x object region information extracted. ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Accessing confidence/consistency region data — regions
text: tibble relevant information uncertainty quantification chosen diagnostic (Murphy curve, reliability curve, ROC curve, score decomposition) supplied forecasting methods. Murphy curve, tibble columns: forecast, threshold, lower, upper, method, level. reliability curve, tibble columns: forecast, x (forecast values), lower, upper, method, level. ROC curve, tibble columns: forecast, FAR (false alarm rate), HR (hit rate), method, level. tibble twice long Murphy reliability curves, since FAR-HR pairs ordered describe polygon, generated pointwise confidence intervals along diagonal lines slope \(-\pi_0/\pi_1\). , \(\pi_1 = 1 - \pi_0\) unconditional event probability.

title: Accessing confidence/consistency region data — regions
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych")  # Bootstrap resampling is expensive # (the number of bootstrap samples is small to keep execution times short) tr <- triptych(ex_binary) |>   dplyr::slice(1, 9) |>   add_confidence(level = 0.9, method = "resampling_cases", n_boot = 20)  regions(tr$murphy) #> # A tibble: 2,000 × 6 #>    forecast threshold    lower    upper method              level #>    <chr>        <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl> <chr>               <dbl> #>  1 X01        0       0        0        resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  2 X01        0.00100 0.000617 0.000759 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  3 X01        0.00200 0.00113  0.00144  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  4 X01        0.00300 0.00162  0.00208  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  5 X01        0.00400 0.00207  0.00271  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  6 X01        0.00501 0.00256  0.00332  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  7 X01        0.00601 0.00302  0.00395  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  8 X01        0.00701 0.00339  0.00450  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  9 X01        0.00801 0.00383  0.00508  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> 10 X01        0.00901 0.00427  0.00568  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> # ℹ 1,990 more rows regions(tr$reliability) #> # A tibble: 1,998 × 6 #>    forecast        x lower upper method              level #>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>               <dbl> #>  1 X01      1.19e-23     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  2 X01      3.84e-23     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  3 X01      9.45e-22     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  4 X01      9.82e-20     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  5 X01      1.13e-19     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  6 X01      4.73e-17     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  7 X01      1.40e-16     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  8 X01      6.33e-16     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  9 X01      1.48e-15     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> 10 X01      7.97e-15     0     0 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> # ℹ 1,988 more rows regions(tr$roc) #> # A tibble: 4,004 × 5 #>    forecast   FAR      HR method              level #>    <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>               <dbl> #>  1 X01          0 0       resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  2 X01          0 0.00209 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  3 X01          0 0.00418 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  4 X01          0 0.00628 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  5 X01          0 0.00837 resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  6 X01          0 0.0105  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  7 X01          0 0.0126  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  8 X01          0 0.0146  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #>  9 X01          0 0.0167  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> 10 X01          0 0.0188  resampling_cases_20   0.9 #> # what: Evaluation of forecasts using reliability curves — reliability
title: Evaluation of forecasts using reliability curves — reliability
text: reliability curve visualizes miscalibration displaying (isotonic) conditional event probability forecast value.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using reliability curves — reliability
code: reliability(x, y = NULL, ...)  as_reliability(x, r)

title: Evaluation of forecasts using reliability curves — reliability
text: x data frame, list, matrix, object can coerced tibble. Contains numeric forecasts. y numeric vector observations. missing, column name "y" must present tibble coerced x. ... Unused. r reference triptych_mcbdsc object whose attributes used casting.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using reliability curves — reliability
text: triptych_reliability object, vctrs_vctr subclass, length equal number forecasting methods supplied x. entry named according corresponding forecasting method, contains list named objects: estimate: data frame isotonic regression estimate. region: Either empty list, data frame pointwise consistency confidence intervals added add_consistency() add_confidence(), respectively. x: numeric vector original forecasts. Access convenient estimates(), regions(), forecasts().

title: Evaluation of forecasts using reliability curves — reliability
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych")  rel <- reliability(ex_binary) rel #> <triptych_reliability[10]> #>             X01             X02             X03             X04             X05  #> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]>  #>             X06             X07             X08             X09             X10  #> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]>   # 1. Choose 4 predictions # 2. Visualize # 3. Adjust the title of the legend rel[c(1, 3, 6, 9)] |>   autoplot() +   ggplot2::guides(colour = ggplot2::guide_legend("Forecast"))     # Build yourself using accessors library(ggplot2) df_est <- estimates(rel[c(1, 3, 6, 9)]) ggplot(df_est, aes(x = x, y = CEP, col = forecast)) +   geom_segment(aes(x = 0, y = 0, xend = 1, yend = 1)) +   geom_path()

what: Bootstrap (binary) observation resampling for triptych objects — resampling_Bernoulli.triptych_murphy
title: Bootstrap (binary) observation resampling for triptych objects — resampling_Bernoulli.triptych_murphy
text: function intended called add_consistency() add_confidence(), specifying "resampling_Bernoulli" respective method argument.

title: Bootstrap (binary) observation resampling for triptych objects — resampling_Bernoulli.triptych_murphy
code: # S3 method for triptych_murphy resampling_Bernoulli(x, level = 0.9, n_boot = 1000, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_reliability resampling_Bernoulli(   x,   level = 0.9,   n_boot = 1000,   position = c("diagonal", "estimate"),   ... )  resampling_Bernoulli(x, level = 0.9, n_boot = 1000, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_roc resampling_Bernoulli(x, level = 0.9, n_boot = 1000, ...)

title: Bootstrap (binary) observation resampling for triptych objects — resampling_Bernoulli.triptych_murphy
text: x One triptych objects. level single value determines quantiles bootstrap sample return. quantiles envelop level * n_boot bootstrap draws. n_boot number bootstrap samples. ... Additional arguments passed methods. position Either "estimate" confidence regions, "diagonal" consistency regions.

title: Bootstrap (binary) observation resampling for triptych objects — resampling_Bernoulli.triptych_murphy
text: list tibbles contain information draw confidence regions. length equal number forecasting methods x.

title: Bootstrap (binary) observation resampling for triptych objects — resampling_Bernoulli.triptych_murphy
text: Bootstrap (binary) observation resampling assumes conditionally independent observations given forecast value. given number bootstrap samples basis pointwise computed confidence/consistency intervals. every bootstrap sample, sample observations Bernoulli distribution conditional (recalibrated) forecast values.

title: Bootstrap (binary) observation resampling for triptych objects — resampling_Bernoulli.triptych_murphy
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych")  # Bootstrap resampling is expensive # (the number of bootstrap samples is small to keep execution times short)  tr_consistency <- triptych(ex_binary) |>   dplyr::slice(1, 9) |>   add_consistency(method = "resampling_Bernoulli", n_boot = 20)  tr_confidence <- triptych(ex_binary) |>   dplyr::slice(1, 9) |>   add_confidence(method = "resampling_Bernoulli", n_boot = 20)

what: Bootstrap case resampling for triptych objects — resampling_cases.triptych_murphy
title: Bootstrap case resampling for triptych objects — resampling_cases.triptych_murphy
text: function intended called add_confidence(), specifying "resampling_cases" method argument.

title: Bootstrap case resampling for triptych objects — resampling_cases.triptych_murphy
code: # S3 method for triptych_murphy resampling_cases(x, level = 0.9, n_boot = 1000, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_reliability resampling_cases(x, level = 0.9, n_boot = 1000, ...)  resampling_cases(x, level = 0.9, n_boot = 1000, ...)  # S3 method for triptych_roc resampling_cases(x, level = 0.9, n_boot = 1000, ...)

title: Bootstrap case resampling for triptych objects — resampling_cases.triptych_murphy
text: x One triptych objects. level single value determines quantiles bootstrap sample return. quantiles envelop level * n_boot bootstrap draws. n_boot number bootstrap samples. ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Bootstrap case resampling for triptych objects — resampling_cases.triptych_murphy
text: list tibbles contain information draw confidence regions. length equal number forecasting methods x.

title: Bootstrap case resampling for triptych objects — resampling_cases.triptych_murphy
text: Case resampling assumes independent identically distributed forecast-observation pairs. given number bootstrap samples basis pointwise computed confidence/consistency intervals. every bootstrap sample, draw forecast-observations pairs replacement size original data set reached.

title: Bootstrap case resampling for triptych objects — resampling_cases.triptych_murphy
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych")  # Bootstrap resampling is expensive # (the number of bootstrap samples is small to keep execution times short)  tr_consistency <- triptych(ex_binary) |>   dplyr::slice(1, 9) |>   add_consistency(level = 0.9, method = "resampling_Bernoulli", n_boot = 20)  tr_confidence <- triptych(ex_binary) |>   dplyr::slice(1, 9) |>   add_confidence(level = 0.9, method = "resampling_cases", n_boot = 20)

what: Evaluation of forecasts using ROC curves — roc
title: Evaluation of forecasts using ROC curves — roc
text: ROC curve visualizes discrimination ability displaying hit rate false alarm rate threshold values.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using ROC curves — roc
code: roc(x, y = NULL, concave = TRUE, ...)  as_roc(x, r)

title: Evaluation of forecasts using ROC curves — roc
text: x data frame, list, matrix, object can coerced tibble. Contains numeric forecasts. y numeric vector observations. missing, column name "y" must present tibble coerced x. concave boolean value indicating whether calculate concave hull raw ROC diagnostic. ... Unused. r reference triptych_mcbdsc object whose attributes used casting.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using ROC curves — roc
text: triptych_roc object, vctrs_vctr subclass, length equal number forecasting methods supplied x. entry named according corresponding forecasting method, contains list named objects: estimate: data frame hit rates false rates. region: Either empty list, data frame pointwise confidence intervals (along diagonal lines slope \(-\pi_0/\pi_1\)) added add_confidence(). x: numeric vector original forecasts. Access convenient estimates(), regions(), forecasts().

title: Evaluation of forecasts using ROC curves — roc
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych")  rc <- roc(ex_binary) rc #> <triptych_roc[10]> #>             X01             X02             X03             X04             X05  #> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]>  #>             X06             X07             X08             X09             X10  #> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]>   # 1. Choose 4 predictions # 2. Visualize # 3. Adjust the title of the legend rc[c(1, 3, 6, 9)] |>   autoplot() +   ggplot2::guides(colour = ggplot2::guide_legend("Forecast"))     # Build yourself using accessors library(ggplot2) df_est <- estimates(rc[c(1, 3, 6, 9)]) ggplot(df_est, aes(x = FAR, y = HR, col = forecast)) +   geom_segment(aes(x = 0, y = 0, xend = 1, yend = 1)) +   geom_path()

title: Internal vctrs methods — triptych-vctrs

what: Evaluation of forecasts using a Triptych — triptych
title: Evaluation of forecasts using a Triptych — triptych
text: triptych visualizes three important aspects predictive performance: Economic utility via Murphy curves, miscalibration via reliability curves, discrimination ability via ROC curves. triptych S3 class plotting methods ggplot2.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using a Triptych — triptych
code: triptych(x, y = NULL, ...)

title: Evaluation of forecasts using a Triptych — triptych
text: x data frame, list, matrix, object can coerced tibble. Contains numeric forecasts. y numeric vector observations. missing, column name "y" must present tibble coerced x. ... Additional arguments passed murphy(), reliability(), roc(), mcbdsc().

title: Evaluation of forecasts using a Triptych — triptych
text: triptych object, tibble subclass, contains five columns: forecast: Contains names. murphy: Contains vctrs_vctr subclass Murphy curves. reliability: Contains vctrs_vctr subclass reliability curves. roc: Contains vctrs_vctr subclass ROC curves. mcbdsc: Contains vctrs_vctr subclass score decompositions.

title: Evaluation of forecasts using a Triptych — triptych
code: data(ex_binary, package = "triptych")  tr <- triptych(ex_binary) tr #> # A tibble: 10 × 5 #>    forecast          murphy     reliability             roc          mcbdsc #>    <chr>         <trpt_mur>      <trpt_rel>      <trpt_roc>   <trpt_mcbdsc> #>  1 X01      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  2 X02      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  3 X03      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  4 X04      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  5 X05      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  6 X06      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  7 X07      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  8 X08      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #>  9 X09      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> #> 10 X10      <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]> <named list[3]>  # 1. Choose 4 predictions # 2. Add consistency bands (for reliability curves) #    (Bootstrap resampling is expensive, the number of bootstrap samples #     is small to keep execution times short) # 3. Create patchwork object # 4. Adjust the title of the legend dplyr::slice(tr, 1, 3, 6, 9) |>   add_consistency(level = 0.9, method = "resampling_Bernoulli", n_boot = 20) |>   autoplot() &   ggplot2::guides(colour = ggplot2::guide_legend("Forecast"))
